intro: Hosackia nudiflora, commonly known as the nakedflower false indigo, is a flowering plant native to the central and eastern United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces raceme-like clusters of small, white to pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soils, making it a suitable choice for native gardens. Hosackia nudiflora is also valued for its ability to fix nitrogen in the soil, contributing to soil fertility.
